details.flavorText: Often tasked with patrolling the borders of their lands, boggard scouts learn to speak another language (typically Common) to make it easier to issue threats and insults toward trespassers.

description.value: This weapon has a short shaft ending in a metal ball studded with spikes.
Little more than a leather cup attached to a pair of straps, a sling can be used to fling smooth stones or sling bullets at a range.
A mix of flexible and molded boiled leather, a suit of this type of armor provides some protection with maximum flexibility.
These are small metal balls, typically either iron or lead, designed to be used as ammunition in slings.

A monster with darkvision can see perfectly well in areas of darkness and dim light, though such vision is in black and white only. Some forms of magical darkness, such as a 4th-level @Compendium[pf2e.spells-srd.Darkness]{Darkness} spell, block normal darkvision. A monster with @Compendium[pf2e.bestiary-ability-glossary-srd.Greater Darkvision]{Greater Darkvision}, however, can see through even these forms of magical darkness.
A boggard scout ignores difficult terrain caused by swamp terrain features.

The boggard scout unleashes a terrifying croak. Any non-boggard within 30 feet becomes @Compendium[pf2e.conditionitems.Frightened]{Frightened 1} unless they succeed at a Will save; those who critically succeed are temporarily immune for 1 minute.

If the boggard scout hits a creature with its tongue, that creature becomes @Compendium[pf2e.conditionitems.Grabbed]{Grabbed} by the boggard. Unlike with a normal grab, the creature isn't @Compendium[pf2e.conditionitems.Immobilized]{Immobilized}, but it can't move beyond the reach of the boggard's tongue.

A creature can sever the tongue by hitting AC 13 and dealing at least 2 slashing damage. Though this doesn't deal any damage to the boggard, it prevents it from using its tongue Strike until it regrows its tongue, which takes a week.
